title: 104_s1957
content: The Act is titled the "Intermodal Safe Container Transportation Amendments Act of 1996" and it amends Title 49 of the United States Code. It also includes definitions for certain terms. In the "Intermodal Safe Container Transportation Amendments Act of 1996," Section 5901 is amended to include definitions from section 13102 of this title. The definition of 'gross cargo weight' is added as the weight of cargo, packaging materials, pallets, and dunnage. Prior Notification.--Section 5902 is amended to require written or electronic notification before tendering containers or trailers for intermodal transportation, with specific weight thresholds and communication methods specified. The subsection applies to individuals in the US tendering containers or trailers for intermodal transportation if the first carrier is a motor carrier. Certification is required for containers or trailers with a gross cargo weight over 29,000 pounds, to be provided in writing or electronically before tendering. The certification requirements for containers or trailers with a gross cargo weight over 29,000 pounds include details such as actual weight, contents description, certifying party identity, container/trailer number, and date of certification. Carriers can transfer certification data to another document or electronic format for forwarding, noting the transfer date and the party performing the transfer. The certification requirements for containers or trailers with a gross cargo weight over 29,000 pounds include details such as actual weight, contents description, certifying party identity, container/trailer number, and date of certification. Shipping documents prepared by the person who tenders a container or trailer to a carrier must meet specific information requirements. The term 'Freight All Kinds' or 'FAK' cannot be used for certification after December 31, 2000, if any commodity's weight in the container or trailer equals or exceeds 20 percent of the total weight. The subsection addresses the marking requirements for a separate document used for intermodal certification and its applicability to individuals tendering containers or trailers for transportation within the United States. The subsequent carrier can presume no certification is required when the container or trailer is tendered. If information is inaccurately transferred or not forwarded, the liable party must cover any incurred costs or penalties. The subsequent carrier incurs costs or penalties if inaccurate information is transferred or certification is not forwarded as required. Liabilities include bond, fine, penalty, storage costs, interest, and legal fees. If a subsequent carrier exercises its lien rights under section 5905, they are liable for the lien amount and related costs, including court and legal fees. Notification and certification requirements do not apply to certain intermodal containers or trailers. Intermodal containers or trailers with consolidated shipments loaded by a motor carrier are subject to weight-related fines or penalties incurred during the highway transportation. Intermodal containers or trailers with consolidated shipments loaded by a motor carrier are subject to weight-related fines or penalties incurred during highway transportation. SEC. 5. PROHIBITIONS. Section 5903 is amended to include provisions regarding the transportation of intermodal containers or trailers by motor carriers. If no certification is received before or when a loaded container is tendered, the carrier may presume the weight is less than 29,001 pounds. A copy of the certification is not required to accompany the container. Section 5903 is amended to include provisions for the transportation of intermodal containers or trailers by motor carriers. If no certification is received, the carrier may presume the weight is less than 29,001 pounds. SEC. 6. LIENS. Section 5905 is amended to address situations where a person involved in intermodal transportation of a loaded container or trailer is required to post a bond or pay fines due to violations of weight laws or regulations. This includes cases of erroneous information in certifications, failure to provide certifications, or errors in information transfer. Section 5905 is amended to address errors in information transfer on certifications for intermodal transportation. If there is an error, the person posting the bond or paying fines has a lien against the contents until payment is received from the owner or responsible party. The lien remains until payment is received for all costs and expenses. SEC. 7 amends Section 5906 regarding perishable agricultural commodities. SEC. 8 addresses regulations and the effective date. SEC. 8 of the Intermodal Safe Container Transportation Amendments Act of 1996 addresses regulations and the effective date. The Secretary of Transportation must initiate a proceeding within 30 days of enactment to consider adopting or modifying regulations. Final regulations, if needed, must be prescribed within 90 days. The chapter becomes effective on the date of enactment, with provisions to be implemented 180 days later. SEC. 9 of the Intermodal Safe Container Transportation Amendments Act of 1996 clarifies that the new chapter does not impact existing laws related to transportation of hazardous materials or state regulations on tractor-trailer combinations.
